tasks.title: TECH DEBT: Audit and eliminate hardcoded values - enforce schema-driven design
tasks.description:
Found hardcoded phase structures in migration (fixed in v0.13.3), but this is likely systemic. Need comprehensive audit:

KNOWN ISSUES:
- lib/migrate.sh had hardcoded 4-phase structure (fixed - now reads from template)
- lib/todowrite-integration.sh has verb mappings that may need review
- scripts/benchmark-performance.sh has hardcoded phase array for tests
- scripts/phases.sh has hardcoded examples in help text
- Likely MORE throughout codebase

AUDIT SCOPE:
1. Find ALL hardcoded values that should derive from schemas/templates
2. Identify validation logic duplicated across scripts vs centralized in lib/
3. Check for magic strings/numbers that should be constants
4. Review enum values (status, priority, phase status) - are they schema-derived?
5. Check default values - do they match schema defaults?

PRINCIPLES TO ENFORCE:
- SINGLE SOURCE OF TRUTH: schemas/*.json and templates/*.json
- DRY: No duplicate definitions of structures/enums/defaults
- SOLID: Scripts should depend on abstractions (lib functions), not concrete values
- Schema-driven: Runtime should validate against and derive from schemas

DELIVERABLES:
- Comprehensive grep/audit report of all hardcoded values
- Prioritized list of violations by severity
- Refactoring plan with helper functions to centralize
- Tests to prevent regression (schema drift detection)

Related: v0.13.3 fix for migration phase hardcoding

tasks.title: CHORE: Implement memory retention automation script
tasks.description:
Create scripts/cleanup-memories.sh to automate memory lifecycle management per retention policy.

POLICY CATEGORIES:
1. permanent (indefinite): project_purpose.md, project_*.md - core identity
2. reference (indefinite, quarterly review): tech_stack.md, code_style_*.md, *_checklist.md
3. philosophy (indefinite): *-philosophy.md, *-principles.md
4. session-handoff (14 days): session-handoff-*.md, session-*.md
5. task-completion (30 days → archive): t*-complete-*.md
6. pending-work (delete when resolved): *-pending.md, *-blocked.md

SCRIPT REQUIREMENTS:
- --dry-run flag for preview
- Age-based deletion for session files (14 days)
- Archive support for task-completion files (30 days)
- Task status checking via claude-todo exists for pending-work files
- Verbose output showing what would be deleted/archived
- Integration with claude-todo validate for safety

CLEANUP RULES:
- session-handoff: delete if age > 14 days AND no unresolved tasks
- task-completion: archive to .serena/memories/archive/ if age > 30 days
- pending-work: delete when all referenced T### tasks have status=done

ARCHIVE STRUCTURE:
- Path: .serena/memories/archive/YYYY-MM/filename.md
- Preserve original timestamps
- Compress after 90 days (optional)

VALIDATION:
- Verify task IDs exist before deciding on pending-work deletion
- Check session-handoff dates against file modification time
- Report any anomalies

- docs/specs/MULTI-AGENT-ABSTRACTION-SPEC.md (authoritative)
- claudedocs/CLEO-Rebrand/research/MULTI-AGENT-ABSTRACTION-PLAN.md

**Deferred From**: T650 (CLEO Rebrand v1.0.0)
**Target**: v2.0.0+ or post-Python migration

**Note**: Design principles are language-agnostic. Implementation will align with future tech stack (Python/DuckDB).

tasks.title: FEATURE: Add 'persistent' field for evergreen epics
tasks.description: Add persistent: true boolean to prevent epic auto-completion. See task notes for full research findings.

tasks.title: FEATURE: Add persistent field for evergreen epics
notes: 2025-12-26 14:53:17 UTC: PROBLEM STATEMENT: claude-todo auto-completes epics when all children are done. This breaks evergreen categories like Tech Debt, Bugs, Research that should persist indefinitely.

2025-12-26 19:13:35 UTC: 5-AGENT RESEARCH CONSENSUS (2025-12-26): All 5 research agents (Evergreen Patterns, Bug Tracking, Tech Debt, Schema Analysis, Task Placement) converged on the same conclusion: Add a simple 'persistent: true' boolean field. This is the minimal, backward-compatible solution that provides explicit user intent without introducing new types or complex patterns.

2025-12-26 19:13:55 UTC: INDUSTRY PATTERNS ANALYZED: (1) Jira - Initiatives vs Epics, no auto-complete by default; (2) Linear - Projects are time-bound, Initiatives are persistent, warns against evergreen projects; (3) GitHub Issues - Labels for categories, no parent-child auto-completion; (4) Azure DevOps - Configurable rules per work item type. Key insight: Industry leaders separate 'completable deliverables' from 'persistent categories' either through type differentiation or configuration flags.

2025-12-26 19:14:18 UTC: SCHEMA RECOMMENDATION: Add 'persistent' field (not 'autoComplete: false' - avoids double negative). Field is orthogonal to status and type, self-documenting, lives where it applies (on the epic itself). Default false preserves current behavior. LLM-agent-friendly: explicit intent, no cross-referencing needed. Evaluation score: Schema complexity LOW, Migration TRIVIAL, User understanding HIGH, Backward compat EXCELLENT.

2025-12-26 19:14:33 UTC: IMPLEMENTATION SCOPE: (1) schemas/todo.schema.json - add persistent boolean field; (2) lib/hierarchy.sh - check persistent flag in handle_parent_auto_complete(); (3) scripts/add-task.sh - add --persistent flag for epic creation; (4) scripts/update-task.sh - add --persistent/--no-persistent toggles; (5) scripts/complete-task.sh - respect persistent in auto-complete logic; (6) tests/unit/hierarchy.bats - test persistent behavior; (7) docs/ - document flag usage. Complexity: Small/Medium scope, single focused PR.

2025-12-26 19:14:51 UTC: WHY NOT ALTERNATIVES: (1) Sentinel Task Pattern - REJECTED: Hacky, pollutes task lists, blocks 100% completion metrics; (2) New 'bucket' Type - REJECTED: Type proliferation, muddies epic->task->subtask hierarchy, harder to convert existing epics; (3) Status 'evergreen' - REJECTED: Semantic violation (status is lifecycle, not behavior), breaks status filtering; (4) Label Convention - REJECTED: Hidden/implicit behavior, typo-prone, no schema validation; (5) Config persistentEpics list - REJECTED: Indirection, ID-coupling, config drift risk. The 'persistent' field wins on all criteria.

2025-12-26 19:15:08 UTC: USE CASES FOR PERSISTENT EPICS: (1) Tech Debt Backlog - ongoing remediation, never truly complete; (2) Bug Triage - continuous inflow of issues; (3) Research/Exploration - open-ended investigation; (4) Maintenance - recurring operational tasks; (5) Documentation - living docs that evolve. These categories benefit from epic organization (hierarchy, progress visibility) but should not auto-close when current children complete.
tasks.description:
Add optional 'persistent: true' boolean field to task schema that prevents auto-completion when all children are done. For evergreen/bucket epics like Tech Debt, Bugs, Research, Maintenance that should never auto-close.

SCHEMA CHANGE (schemas/todo.schema.json):
  persistent: { type: boolean, default: false }

CLI INTEGRATION:
  claude-todo add 'Tech Debt' --type epic --persistent
  claude-todo update T001 --persistent true

FILES TO MODIFY:
  - schemas/todo.schema.json
  - lib/hierarchy.sh  
  - scripts/add-task.sh
  - scripts/update-task.sh
  - scripts/complete-task.sh
  - tests/unit/hierarchy.bats
  - docs/

See notes for full 5-agent research consensus and analysis.

tasks.description:
JQ BATCHING OPTIMIZATION - Analysis Complete, Implementation Pending

SCOPE:

TOP 5 FILES (Priority Order):
1. find.bats - 54 calls (6.9% density)
2. delete-preview.bats - 52 calls (12.6% density - highest)
3. archive-stats.bats - 50 calls (7.5% density)
4. test-2.2.0-migration.bats - 65 calls (8.9% density)
5. schema-validation.bats - 29 calls (2.3% density)

COMMON ANTI-PATTERNS TO FIX:
Pattern A - Multiple select+extract (200+ instances):
  # CURRENT: 2 subprocess calls
  id=$(echo "$output" | jq -r '.items[] | select(.id == "T001") | .id')
  title=$(echo "$output" | jq -r '.items[] | select(.id == "T001") | .title')
  # OPTIMIZED: 1 subprocess call
  data=$(echo "$output" | jq -r '.items[] | select(.id == "T001") | {id, title}')

Pattern B - Count then access (150+ instances):
  # CURRENT: 3 calls
  count=$(echo "$output" | jq '.array | length')
  first=$(echo "$output" | jq '.array[0]')
  # OPTIMIZED: 1 call
  data=$(echo "$output" | jq '{count: (.array | length), first: .array[0]}')

Pattern C - Sequential field checks (100+ instances):
  # CURRENT: Multiple calls for optional fields
  # OPTIMIZED: Single object extraction

IMPLEMENTATION PHASES:
Phase 1 (Quick Wins): archive-stats.bats, list-tasks.bats, hierarchy-workflow.bats
Phase 2 (Medium): find.bats, delete-preview.bats
Phase 3 (Complex): test-2.2.0-migration.bats

tasks.title: Optimize stats command performance - exceeds 1000ms target at 1000+ tasks
tasks.description: The stats command exceeds the 1000ms performance target when processing 1000+ tasks. Benchmark data shows 1726ms mean at 1000 tasks (target: <1000ms). This impacts LLM agent efficiency as stats is called frequently for project overview. Root cause analysis and optimization needed in scripts/stats.sh and potentially lib/analysis.sh.
notes:
2025-12-27 05:22:39 UTC: ## Benchmark Data (2025-12-27)

### Performance Results
| Dataset | Mean | Min | Max | Target | Status |
|---------|------|-----|-----|--------|--------|
| 100 tasks | 1988ms | 1791ms | 2151ms | N/A | PASS (threshold only for 1000+) |
| 500 tasks | 1834ms | 1762ms | 1927ms | N/A | PASS |
| 1000 tasks | 1726ms | 1686ms | 1771ms | <1000ms | FAIL |

### Observations
1. Performance is relatively consistent (low variance ~5%)
2. Counterintuitively SLOWER with fewer tasks (1988ms@100 vs 1726ms@1000)
3. Likely fixed overhead dominates - jq startup, file I/O, subprocess spawning

### Suspected Bottlenecks (to investigate)
1. scripts/stats.sh - Main entry point
2. lib/analysis.sh - Task analysis functions  
3. Multiple jq invocations instead of single pass
4. Potential redundant file reads
5. Subprocess spawning overhead

### Impact
- LLM agents call stats frequently for project overview
- 1.7s latency per call compounds over session
- Target: <1000ms for 1000+ task datasets

### Comparison: list command
- list at 1000 tasks: 1ms (extremely fast)
- stats at 1000 tasks: 1726ms (1726x slower)
- Suggests stats-specific logic is the bottleneck, not file I/O

tasks.title: Centralize session error handling in error-json.sh
tasks.description:
T1042 fix works but violates architecture by using inline JSON building instead of centralized helpers.

**Current State (T1042 implementation):**
- Discovery mode and resume-when-active use `output_error_actionable` directly
- JSON for `fix`, `alternatives`, `context` built inline in session.sh and sessions.sh
- Error codes `E_SESSION_DISCOVERY_MODE` not in centralized mapping

**Required Refactoring:**
1. Add missing error codes to error-json.sh:
   - `E_SESSION_DISCOVERY_MODE` (exit 100)
   - `E_SESSION_RESUME_ACTIVE` (exit 30, distinct from E_SESSION_EXISTS)

2. Add new helper functions to error-json.sh:
   - `get_session_error_fix()` - returns copy-paste ready fix command
   - `get_session_error_alternatives()` - returns JSON array of {action, command}

3. Enhance `output_session_error()` signature:
   ```bash
   output_session_error "$error_code" "$message" "$exit_code" "$context_json" ["$fix"] ["$alternatives"]
   # OR auto-derive fix/alternatives from error_code via helpers
   ```

4. Replace inline implementations in:
   - scripts/session.sh:390-473 (discovery mode)
   - lib/sessions.sh:752-789 (resume-when-active)

**Benefits:**
- Single source of truth for session error responses
- Consistent error format across all session operations
- Easier to maintain and extend
- Aligns with T1018 intent

**Files to modify:**
- lib/error-json.sh (add helpers, enhance output_session_error)
- scripts/session.sh (use output_session_error)
- lib/sessions.sh (use output_session_error)

Refactor T1042's inline code at session.sh:390-473 (discovery mode) and lib/sessions.sh:766-803 (resume-when-active) to use output_session_error() with appropriate error codes E_SESSION_DISCOVERY_MODE and E_SESSION_RESUME_ACTIVE.

tasks.title: Create lib/orchestrator.sh with spawn and monitor functions
tasks.description:

tasks.title: Add Stop hook notification for orchestrator
tasks.description:
## Objective
Create Stop hook to notify orchestrator when agent completes.

## File Location
.claude/hooks/orchestrator-stop.yaml

## Hook Specification (ORCHESTRATOR-SPEC.md Part 7)
```yaml
name: Orchestrator Completion Notifier
trigger: Stop
when: \$CLEO_ORCHESTRATION_ID \!= ""
actions:
  - bash: |
      event_dir="\${CLEO_PROJECT_ROOT}/.cleo/orchestration/events"
      mkdir -p "\$event_dir"
      event_file="\${event_dir}/\${CLEO_SESSION}_complete.json"
      jq -nc \\
        --arg session "\$CLEO_SESSION" \\
        --arg agent "\$CLEO_AGENT_ID" \\
        --arg status "\$EXIT_STATUS" \\
        --arg wave "\$CLEO_WAVE" \\
        --arg timestamp "\$(date -u +%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ)" \\
        '{session: \$session, agent: \$agent, exitStatus: (\$status | tonumber), wave: (\$wave | tonumber), completedAt: \$timestamp}' > "\$event_file"
```

## Event Schema
```json
{
  "session": "session_xxx",
  "agent": "agent_01",
  "exitStatus": 0,
  "wave": 1,
  "completedAt": "ISO8601"
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] File exists at .claude/hooks/orchestrator-stop.yaml
- [ ] Triggers only when CLEO_ORCHESTRATION_ID is set
- [ ] Creates event file in .cleo/orchestration/events/
- [ ] Event JSON validates against schema
- [ ] Works with Claude Code Stop hook system
- [ ] Does not block on completion

## References
- ORCHESTRATOR-SPEC.md Part 7 (Completion Detection)
- Claude Code hooks documentation

tasks.title: Research: NEXUS Protocol Core Principles
tasks.description: Document the core principles of NEXUS: 1) NEXUS defines HOW agents behave/communicate, CLEO handles WHERE they run. 2) Agent protocol is infrastructure-agnostic (works with tmux, docker, cloud). 3) Event-based handoff as primary mechanism, CLI fallback for critical ops. 4) Hybrid schema ownership (CLEO=task state, NEXUS=runtime state).

tasks.title: Research: Agent Communication Protocol
tasks.description: Define the agent communication protocol: event file format, event types (verification_gate, task_complete, focus_change, escalation), correlation IDs, artifact attachments, and error reporting. Include examples and JSON schemas.

tasks.title: Research: NEXUS-CLEO Integration Points
tasks.description: Map the integration points between NEXUS and CLEO: 1) Data access via CLI only. 2) Event processor in CLEO reads NEXUS events. 3) Session/scope binding from CLEO. 4) Verification gate updates. 5) Audit logging in CLEO. Include sequence diagrams for key flows.

tasks.title: Research: NEXUS Runtime State Schema
tasks.description: Design the NEXUS-owned runtime state schema: agent_executions, wave_coordination, agent_configs, performance_metrics. Define what NEXUS owns vs references from CLEO. Consider DuckDB native arrays for efficient storage.

tasks.title: Research: Concurrency Control Strategy
tasks.description: Define the shared concurrency control: CLEO layer (task versioning, scope isolation, file locking) + NEXUS layer (agent coordination, task assignment). Document the layered protection model and failure modes.

tasks.title: Document: Preliminary Decisions from Initial Research
tasks.description: Log preliminary decisions made in initial research session (2026-01-01): 1) NEXUS = agent protocol only, CLEO = infrastructure. 2) CLI commands for data access. 3) Hybrid schema (CLEO owns task state, NEXUS owns runtime state). 4) Shared concurrency control. 5) Event-based handoff with CLI fallback. 6) CLEO owns tmux orchestration. Reference the full integration guide document created.

tasks.title: DISCUSSION: Task dependency health scoring
tasks.description:
## Concept
Score the "health" of dependency chains to identify risks.

## Health Indicators

### Healthy Dependencies
- Short chains (< 3 levels)
- Dependencies actively progressing
- Clear ownership
- No circular risks

### Unhealthy Dependencies
- Deep chains (> 5 levels)
- Stale blockers
- Orphaned tasks in chain
- Single point of failure tasks

## Output Example
```
DEPENDENCY HEALTH
  ✅ T429 chain: HEALTHY (3 levels, active)
  ⚠️ T382 chain: AT RISK (5 levels, T390 stale 21 days)
  🔴 T339 chain: CRITICAL (blocked by completed task - bug?)
```

## Questions
1. How to define "healthy"?
2. What actions to suggest?
3. Auto-fix obvious issues?

## Status
DISCUSSION - Could help with tech debt
notes: 2026-01-02 10:55:10 UTC: BACKLOG: Circular dep detection is genuinely useful. Medium effort (~60 lines). Implement when dependency complexity becomes pain point.

tasks.title: Review session start UX when multiSession disabled
tasks.description:
Review and improve session start behavior when Epic-Bound options are used but multiSession.enabled=false.

**Current Behavior:**
- User runs: cleo session start --scope epic:T001 --agent opus
- Error: E_CONFIG_ERROR 'Multi-session mode not enabled'
- User might fall back to: cleo session start (no scope binding)
- Result: Session starts without scope protection

**Issues:**
1. Error message doesn't suggest enabling multiSession
2. Easy to accidentally start unbound session
3. No warning that scope/agent options were ignored

**Potential Improvements:**
1. Add suggestion to error: 'Run: cleo config set multiSession.enabled true'
2. Or: Auto-enable multiSession when scope options provided?
3. Or: Refuse to start ANY session if scope options given but disabled?
4. Better error message with actionable fix command

tasks.title: Validate agent ID uniqueness across active sessions
tasks.description:
Currently agent IDs are not validated for uniqueness - multiple active sessions can have the same agent ID.

**Current Behavior:**
- Agent ID is optional, stored as-is
- No uniqueness check
- Multiple sessions can have same agentId or null

**Enhancement Options:**
1. Warn if duplicate agent ID in active sessions
2. Error if duplicate (strict mode)
3. Auto-generate unique agent ID if not provided
4. Make configurable: multiSession.requireUniqueAgentId

**Consideration:** 
Is agent ID meant to identify the LLM instance? If so, uniqueness makes sense.
Or is it just metadata? Then duplicates are fine.

tasks.title: Validate scope type is one of known types
tasks.description:
Add validation that scope type is one of the 6 known types.

**Known Scope Types:**
- epic, task, taskGroup, subtree, epicPhase, custom

**Current Behavior:**
- Scope type parsed from --scope argument (e.g., 'epic:T001')
- Unknown types may cause undefined behavior
- No explicit validation error for invalid scope type

**Enhancement:**
1. Validate scope type against known list
2. Return E_INVALID_INPUT with clear message
3. Suggest valid scope types in error message

tasks.title: Auto-generate meaningful session names from scope
tasks.description:
When --name is not provided, auto-generate a meaningful session name from the scope.

**Current Behavior:**
- Session name is optional
- If not provided, stored as null
- Session list shows null names

**Enhancement:**
1. Auto-generate name from scope: 'Epic: T001' or 'Task: T005'
2. Include task title if available: 'Epic: Auth System (T001)'
3. Timestamp suffix for uniqueness if needed
4. Still allow explicit --name to override

**Benefits:**
- Better session list readability
- Easier to identify sessions
- No manual naming required

tasks.title: Parse scope parameter in session resume subcommand
tasks.description: session.sh resume parser silently ignores scope parameter with catch-all pattern. User scope is dropped silently. Should parse and filter by scope or error if no match.
notes: 2025-12-29 18:05:24 UTC: LLM-AGENT-FIRST PRINCIPLE: Silent parameter drops are catastrophic for agents. They construct commands based on their understanding and expect explicit feedback. Silently ignoring --scope means agents cannot trust the command executed what they intended. Must either parse the parameter OR return an error explaining the parameter is not supported.

tasks.title: Add compliance checks for session exit codes and suggestions
tasks.description: Add to check-compliance.sh: 1) Verify session errors use 30-39 range, 2) Every output_error call includes suggestion, 3) No generic exit 4 for session-specific errors, 4) No stderr when FORMAT=json
notes: 2025-12-29 18:05:47 UTC: LLM-AGENT-FIRST PRINCIPLE: Compliance checks ensure CLEO stays agent-friendly as it evolves. Tests verify: (1) exit codes are semantically correct, (2) error responses include actionable suggestions, (3) JSON output is consistent and self-documenting. These are guardrails that prevent regression.

tasks.title: Implement consistent exit 0 vs 100 policy for discovery mode
tasks.description: CRITICAL LLM-AGENT-FIRST: Agents will NEVER see the spec - behavior must be intuitive and self-documenting. CURRENT PROBLEM: Discovery mode returns exit 100 (NO_DATA) but HAS data (epic list). IMPLEMENTATION: Exit 0 with requiresInput:true and suggestedCommand field for interactive prompts. Exit 100 ONLY for true empty results (no matches found). Changes needed in session.sh discovery mode and anywhere exit 100 is used inappropriately.
notes: 2025-12-29 18:05:00 UTC: LLM-AGENT-FIRST PRINCIPLE: Exit codes must be semantically correct without reading documentation. Exit 0 = success (even if user input needed). Exit 100 = genuinely no data. Agents parse exit codes programmatically - they must be predictable and logical.

tasks.title: Fix error cascade in session start with auto-focus
tasks.description: When session start with auto-focus fails, agent sees two errors: E_FOCUS_REQUIRED (38) then E_SESSION_START_FAILED (35). Should be single error with context: E_SESSION_STARTED_FOCUS_FAILED, include session ID that WAS created, provide fix command for focus.
notes: 2025-12-29 18:05:48 UTC: LLM-AGENT-FIRST PRINCIPLE: Error cascades confuse agents. When an operation partially succeeds, agents need clear feedback about what succeeded and what failed, with specific fix commands. Two separate errors for one command forces agents to correlate and deduplicate - they should receive one comprehensive response.

tasks.title: Implement CLEO-native TMUX Agent Orchestration
tasks.description:
## Problem Statement

`.current-session` is a single file shared by all terminals. True multi-terminal support is impossible without a unique identifier per Claude Code conversation.

## Current Workarounds (all inadequate)

1. **`.current-session` file** - Last session start wins, all terminals use same session
2. **CLEO_SESSION env var** - Claude can't modify parent shell environment
3. **`--session` flag** - Requires passing on every command (bad UX)

## Research Findings (from T1013)

- `CLAUDECODE=1` exists but is not unique per conversation
- No `CLAUDE_CODE_SESSION_ID` or similar exposed
- TTY returns 'not a tty' in Claude Code bash
- PPID changes between commands

## Potential Solutions

1. **Feature Request to Anthropic**: Expose conversation ID as env var
2. **Claude Code Hook**: SessionStart hook that sets CLEO_SESSION
3. **Scope-based auto-detection**: If command targets T998 task, auto-use T998 session
4. **Process tree detection**: Track parent process hierarchy
5. **Accept limitation**: Document that multi-session requires manual `--session` flag

## Success Criteria

- 5 terminals can run 5 different sessions concurrently without interference
- No manual `--session` flag or env var export required
- Each Claude Code conversation auto-identifies itself

tasks.title: EPIC: LLM-Agent-First JSON Output System with Smart Pagination
tasks.description: Fix JSON truncation issues and implement smart pagination/sorting across all commands to comply with LLM-AGENT-FIRST-SPEC.md. Current issue: 'cleo session list' returns all 91 sessions (79KB) causing tool truncation. Solution: centralized lib/json-output.sh with pagination, smart defaults (lastActivity DESC, limit 20), and consistent compact JSON output (-c flag).

tasks.title: RESEARCH: Audit current JSON output patterns across all 34 commands
tasks.description: Systematically audit all 34 commands listed in LLM-AGENT-FIRST-SPEC.md Part 1 to identify which use jq -n (pretty) vs jq -nc (compact) vs jq -c (compact). Document current behavior: whether they use pagination, sorting, limits. Primary focus: session list, list, log, history (likely unbounded). Secondary: labels, phases, deps, blockers (likely OK). Create audit matrix: Command | Current jq flags | Has pagination | Has sorting | Estimated max output size.
notes:
2026-01-04 22:07:06 UTC: ## Research Context (2026-01-04)

**Trigger**: User reported 'cleo session list' truncation showing '... [1 lines truncated] ...' when returning all 91 sessions (79KB output).

**Root Cause Analysis**:
1. Truncation occurred at Claude Code tool result rendering layer (not CLI bug)
2. Exposed LLM-Agent-First design flaw: no smart defaults for large datasets
3. scripts/session.sh:1469-1477 dumps ALL sessions unsorted with no pagination

**Current State Findings**:
- lib/error-json.sh: Uses jq -c (compact) correctly per line 146 comment
- scripts/session.sh: Uses jq -nc for success output (no compact flag\!)
- Most commands use jq -n (pretty) which causes multi-line truncation risk

**Commands Likely Affected**:
- session list (confirmed: 91 sessions, 79KB, no sort/limit)
- list (could have 1000s of tasks)
- log (unbounded audit log)
- history (unbounded timeline)

**Evidence Files**:
- lib/error-json.sh:142-146 (correct compact pattern with rationale comment)
- scripts/session.sh:1469-1477 (session list JSON output - no pagination)
- docs/specs/LLM-AGENT-FIRST-SPEC.md (authoritative standard)

**Previous Work**: T672 (archived 2025-12-23) fixed tree rendering truncation for TEXT format only, NOT JSON pagination.

tasks.title: RESEARCH: Document CLI pagination patterns and best practices
tasks.description: Research how other CLIs handle pagination for large datasets. Analyze: 1) GitHub CLI (gh) - how does 'gh pr list' handle 1000s of PRs? 2) kubectl - how does 'kubectl get pods' handle large clusters? 3) AWS CLI - pagination patterns. 4) jq itself - streaming vs slurp modes. Document: Default limits, --limit flag patterns, --all override flags, sorting defaults, pagination metadata in JSON output (hasMore, nextToken, etc). Create reference doc: claudedocs/research/CLI-Pagination-Patterns.md
notes:
2026-01-04 22:07:43 UTC: ## Key Questions to Answer:

1. What are standard default limits? (10? 20? 50? 100?)
2. How do CLIs indicate 'more results exist'?
3. Cursor-based vs offset-based pagination?
4. Should --all be explicit or implicit unlimited?
5. Performance: at what dataset size does pagination become critical?

## Initial Findings:

**GitHub CLI (gh)**:
- gh pr list: Default limit 30, --limit flag, --state flag for filtering
- JSON output includes pagination URL in headers (not in body)

**kubectl**:
- No limit by default (returns all), but uses server-side pagination internally
- --chunk-size flag for large lists

**AWS CLI**:
- Default: returns first page only
- --max-items flag for limit
- --starting-token for cursor-based pagination
- NextToken in JSON output when more results exist

**Preferred Pattern for CLEO**:
- Default limit: 20 (balance between useful and non-truncating)
- Smart sorting: most relevant first (lastActivity for sessions)
- Pagination metadata in JSON envelope (not separate headers)
- --all flag to override (explicit unlimited)

tasks.title: DESIGN: Create lib/json-output.sh library specification
tasks.description: Design centralized JSON output library with reusable functions for all commands. Must provide: 1) output_json_envelope() - standard _meta wrapper 2) output_json_compact() - force compact mode 3) output_json_array() - array with count metadata 4) output_json_paginated() - array with pagination metadata 5) sort_json_array() - sort by field with asc/desc 6) limit_json_array() - apply limit with truncation flag. Follow error-json.sh pattern (lines 142-146) using jq -c for compact output. Create spec: claudedocs/specs/JSON-OUTPUT-LIBRARY-SPEC.md with function signatures, parameters, return values, examples.
notes:
2026-01-04 22:08:06 UTC: ## Design Requirements (from LLM-AGENT-FIRST-SPEC.md):

**Compact JSON Enforcement** (error-json.sh:142-146 rationale):
- Agents parse JSON programmatically, formatting doesn't matter
- Compact prevents truncation issues ('+N lines')
- Humans can pipe through 'jq .' for pretty output
- ALL success outputs MUST use jq -c flag

**Standard Envelope** (LLM-AGENT-FIRST-SPEC.md Part 3.4):
```json
{
  "\$schema": "https://cleo.dev/schemas/v1/output.schema.json",
  "_meta": {
    "format": "json",
    "version": "<version>",
    "command": "<command-name>",
    "timestamp": "<ISO-8601>"
  },
  "success": true,
  "summary": {},
  "data": []
}
```

**Pagination Metadata** (new requirement):
```json
{
  "_meta": {...},
  "success": true,
  "count": 91,        // Total matching
  "returned": 20,     // Returned in response
  "truncated": true,  // More exist
  "pagination": {
    "limit": 20,
    "offset": 0,
    "hasMore": true,
    "sort": {"field": "lastActivity", "order": "desc"}
  },
  "data": [...]
}
```

**Function Signatures** (draft):
- output_json_envelope(command, data_json) → compact JSON string
- output_json_array(command, array_json, count) → envelope with count
- output_json_paginated(command, array_json, total, limit, offset, sort_field, sort_order) → full pagination envelope
- sort_json_array(array_json, field, order) → sorted array
- limit_json_array(array_json, limit, offset) → {array, truncated, returned}

**Integration Points**:
- Source from scripts/ just like error-json.sh
- Use same VERSION loading pattern
- Compatible with resolve_format() from output-format.sh
- Must work with existing jq-helpers.sh functions

tasks.title: DESIGN: Session list smart defaults specification
tasks.description: Design smart defaults for 'cleo session list' command to prevent truncation. Specify: 1) Default sort: lastActivity DESC (most recent first) 2) Default limit: 20 sessions 3) New flags: --limit N, --all, --sort FIELD, --order asc|desc 4) Pagination metadata in JSON output 5) Text format hints when truncated. Document breaking changes and migration path. Update docs/commands/session.md with new behavior. Cross-reference: scripts/session.sh:1469-1477 (current implementation), LLM-AGENT-FIRST-SPEC.md Part 5 (write command requirements).
notes:
2026-01-04 22:08:32 UTC: ## Current Behavior (scripts/session.sh:1469-1477):

```bash
# Returns ALL sessions, unsorted, no pagination
jq -nc \
  --arg ts "$timestamp" \
  --arg version "${CLEO_VERSION:-$(get_version)}" \
  --arg filter "$status_filter" \
  --argjson sessions "$sessions" \
  '{
    "\$schema": "https://cleo-dev.com/schemas/v1/output.schema.json",
    "_meta": {...},
    "success": true,
    "filter": $filter,
    "count": ($sessions | length),
    "sessions": $sessions  # ← ALL 91 sessions, no limit\!
  }'
```

## Proposed Behavior:

**Default (agent-optimized)**:
```bash
cleo session list
# Returns: Last 20 sessions sorted by lastActivity DESC
# JSON: {"count": 91, "returned": 20, "truncated": true, ...}
# Text: "Showing 20 of 91 sessions (use --all to see all)"
```

**Explicit flags**:
```bash
cleo session list --limit 50          # First 50
cleo session list --all                # Override limit (all 91)
cleo session list --sort startedAt     # Sort by different field
cleo session list --order asc          # Ascending order
cleo session list --status active --limit 10  # Combine with existing filters
```

**Sort Field Options**:
- lastActivity (default) - most recently active
- startedAt - creation order
- status - active first, then suspended, ended
- name - alphabetical

**Breaking Change Analysis**:
- Agents relying on 'all sessions always returned' will break
- Mitigation: Add --all flag, update CLAUDE.md injection, version bump
- Backward compat: Not feasible (defeats purpose), document in CHANGELOG

**Text Format**:
When truncated, show hint:
```
Sessions (20 of 91):
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
● session_20260104... (most recent)
...
○ session_20251215... (20th)

Showing 20 most recent. Use --all to see all 91 sessions.
```

notes: 2026-01-06 05:31:58 UTC: Key decisions: (1) Directory location and hierarchy, (2) Discovery algorithm (glob patterns, manifest file), (3) Global vs project-local recipes, (4) Naming conventions for recipe files. Reference ANALYSIS-WORKFLOWS-INTEGRATION.md section 4.

2026-01-06 05:37:57 UTC: DIRECTORY STRUCTURE RESEARCH - Source: ANALYSIS section 4

LOCATION OPTIONS (priority order):
1. .cleo/recipes/ - Project-local recipes (PRIMARY)
   - Per-project customization
   - Version controlled with project
   - Isolated from other projects

2. ~/.cleo/recipes/ - Global user recipes (SECONDARY)
   - Shared across all projects
   - User-specific workflows
   - Portable across machines via dotfiles

3. /usr/local/share/cleo/recipes/ - System-wide recipes (TERTIARY)
   - Distribution-provided recipes
   - Read-only, requires sudo to modify
   - Standard recipes for all users

DISCOVERY ALGORITHM:
- Glob patterns: .cleo/recipes/**/*.sh
- Manifest file: .cleo/recipes/manifest.json (optional metadata index)
- Precedence: project > user > system
- Naming convention: <category>-<name>.sh (e.g., sprint-setup.sh)

INTEGRATION WITH EXISTING SYSTEMS:
- Use cli.plugins.directories pattern from config.schema.json
- Auto-discover on session start (like autoDiscoveryOnStart)
- Cache manifest for performance (similar to plugin system)

KEY DECISIONS:
1. Support all 3 levels with clear precedence
2. JSON manifest optional but recommended for metadata
3. Shell script based (not Python) for portability
4. Recipe metadata in YAML frontmatter OR separate .json sidecar

tasks.title: Analyze script execution security and validation
tasks.description: Define security boundaries for recipe execution. Address malicious code execution risks in downloaded or AI-generated recipes. Evaluate sandboxing, approval mechanisms, checksums, and signature verification. Design safe execution model.
notes: 2026-01-06 05:32:07 UTC: Security concerns: (1) Arbitrary code execution from untrusted sources, (2) LLM-generated recipes may contain hallucinated commands, (3) Downloaded recipes from web sources, (4) User approval workflows vs automated execution. Must balance security with LLM-agent-first usability. Consider: dry-run mode, approval prompts, checksums, allowlist/blocklist.

2026-01-06 05:38:18 UTC: SECURITY BOUNDARY DESIGN - Source: RESEARCH-PLAN.md Task 2

THREAT MODEL:
1. Arbitrary Code Execution Vectors:
   - LLM-generated recipes (hallucinated commands, incorrect flags)
   - Downloaded recipes from untrusted web sources
   - Modified recipes in version control (supply chain attacks)
   - Recipe parameter injection (shell escaping issues)

2. Data Exfiltration Risks:
   - Recipes accessing sensitive .cleo/*.json files
   - Credential leakage via recipe output
   - Network exfiltration via curl/wget in recipes

3. System Integrity Risks:
   - Destructive file operations (rm -rf)
   - Database corruption (direct JSON edits bypassing validation)
   - Git history manipulation

SECURITY MECHANISMS TO EVALUATE:

Tier 1: Input Validation (MUST HAVE)
- Recipe parameter sanitization and escaping
- Command injection prevention
- Path traversal prevention
- Allowlist of permitted cleo commands

Tier 2: Execution Controls (SHOULD HAVE)
- Dry-run mode (preview without execution)
- User approval prompts for destructive operations
- Recipe checksums (SHA256) for integrity verification
- Recipe signing (GPG) for authenticity

Tier 3: Sandboxing (NICE TO HAVE)
- Restricted environment variables
- Read-only .cleo/ access for recipes
- Network isolation (no curl/wget)
- Filesystem jail (can't access outside project)

APPROVAL WORKFLOWS:
- Auto-approve: Signed recipes from trusted sources
- Prompt approval: Unsigned recipes, first-time execution
- Block: Failed checksum, unsigned from untrusted source

BALANCE WITH AGENT-FIRST:
- LLM agents need minimal friction for productivity
- Approval fatigue reduces usability
- Trust model: gradual allowlisting based on execution history

REFERENCE ARCHITECTURES:
- GitHub Actions security model (job permissions)
- Docker security contexts (capabilities, seccomp)
- npm package audit (vulnerability scanning)

tasks.title: Research position system integration for recipe execution ordering
tasks.description: Investigate how CLEO position system (T805) can be applied to recipe execution. Design explicit work ordering for multi-recipe workflows where execution sequence matters but dependencies don't exist. Enable recipe orchestration based on position rather than just dependency waves.
notes:
2026-01-06 05:39:10 UTC: POSITION SYSTEM CONTEXT - Source: ANALYSIS-TASK-DEPENDENCY-ARCHITECTURE.md Part 3

T805 CAPABILITIES (complete):
- Schema v2.6.0: position (integer, min 1) + positionVersion (conflict detection)
- Scope: Per-parent (sibling ordering, not global)
- Commands: cleo reorder <id> --position N, --before <id>, --after <id>, cleo swap
- Auto-assignment: New tasks get position = max + 1 within sibling group

RECIPE INTEGRATION USE CASES:
1. Sprint workflow: setup → planning → execution → review → cleanup
   - No dependencies between phases, but order matters
   - Position enforces sequence without artificial blocking

2. Release pipeline: build → test → stage → prod
   - Can run in parallel if resources available
   - Position shows recommended order for serial execution

3. Daily standup: yesterday → today → blockers → stats

tasks.title: Design verification gates for recipe quality assurance
tasks.description: Design verification gate system for recipe execution quality. Define gates for: recipe validation, parameter checking, dry-run verification, execution success, output validation. Integrate with T1150 progressive verification epic. Ensure recipes can self-verify before marking complete.
notes:
2026-01-06 05:39:29 UTC: VERIFICATION ARCHITECTURE - Source: ANALYSIS-TASK-DEPENDENCY-ARCHITECTURE.md Part 4

T1150 VERIFICATION SCHEMA (implemented):
Gates: implemented, testsPassed, qaPassed, securityPassed, documented
Object: verification.passed (boolean), round (integer), lastAgent, failureLog
Auto-set: 'cleo complete' sets implemented=true
Manual: 'cleo verify <id> --gate testsPassed'

RECIPE VERIFICATION GATES (proposed):
1. recipeValidated - Recipe metadata and structure valid
2. parametersChecked - All required parameters provided and valid
3. dryRunPassed - Dry-run execution completed without errors
4. executionSuccess - Actual execution completed successfully
5. outputValidated - Output format matches specification

WORKFLOW INTEGRATION:
Recipe execution pipeline:
1. Load recipe → validate metadata → recipeValidated=true
2. Parse parameters → validate types → parametersChecked=true  
3. Execute dry-run → check for errors → dryRunPassed=true
4. Prompt user approval (if required)
5. Execute recipe → monitor exit codes → executionSuccess=true
6. Validate output format → outputValidated=true
→ verification.passed = true (all gates set)

PARENT AUTO-COMPLETE INTEGRATION:
config.json: verification.requireForParentAutoComplete: true
Multi-recipe workflows cannot complete until all recipe tasks verified
Prevents premature workflow completion

REFERENCE IMPLEMENTATION:
- lib/verification.sh functions
- Exit codes 40-47 for verification errors
- T1154-T1162 implementation tasks

tasks.title: Design wave-based recipe dependency management
tasks.description: Research how CLEO wave computation algorithm can be applied to recipe dependency chains. Design recipe dependency declaration format and wave-based execution planning. Enable parallel recipe execution within waves while respecting inter-recipe dependencies.
notes:
2026-01-06 05:40:21 UTC: WAVE COMPUTATION ARCHITECTURE - Source: ANALYSIS-TASK-DEPENDENCY-ARCHITECTURE.md Parts 1, 8

WAVE ALGORITHM (from TASK-HIERARCHY-SPEC Part 6):
wave(task) = max(deps.filter(d => d.status != 'done').map(d => wave(d))) + 1
wave(task with no active deps) = 0

SCOPE FILTERING:
- Dependencies INSIDE scope: Affect wave computation
- Dependencies OUTSIDE scope but done: Treated as satisfied
- Dependencies OUTSIDE scope but NOT done: Task is BLOCKED (not in waves)

RECIPE WAVE USE CASES:

Example: Release Pipeline Recipe
Wave 0: version-update, changelog-draft (parallel - no deps)
Wave 1: run-tests (depends on version-update)
Wave 2: build-artifacts (depends on run-tests)
Wave 3: deploy-staging (depends on build-artifacts)
Wave 4: qa-approval (depends on deploy-staging)
Wave 5: deploy-production (depends on qa-approval)

Example: Sprint Setup Recipe
Wave 0: create-epic, setup-labels (parallel - no deps)
Wave 1: create-feature-tasks (depends on epic)
Wave 2: create-test-tasks (depends on feature tasks)
Wave 3: generate-sprint-board (depends on all tasks)

RECIPE DEPENDENCY DECLARATION:
Option A: Recipe metadata declares dependencies on other recipes
{
  "dependencies": ["setup-epic", "configure-labels"],
  "outputs": ["EPIC_ID", "SPRINT_LABEL"]
}

Option B: Recipe tasks created with explicit dependencies
Recipe creates tasks T001, T002
Next recipe uses --depends T001,T002

PARALLELIZATION OPPORTUNITIES:
- Wave 0 recipes can execute in parallel (no dependencies)
- Within-wave parallelization if recipes independent
- Agent assignment strategy (Agent 1: Wave 0 task A, Agent 2: Wave 0 task B)

CRITICAL PATH ANALYSIS:
- Longest path from Wave 0 → final wave
- Identify bottleneck recipes that gate subsequent waves
- Optimization: Minimize critical path by reordering non-dependent recipes

REFERENCE: ANALYSIS Part 6 (Execution Strategy)

tasks.title: Create recipe execution strategy and parallelization model
tasks.description: Design comprehensive execution strategy for recipes including: agent assignment patterns, parallel execution within waves, critical path optimization, resource management, error handling and rollback. Define how multiple LLM agents can collaborate on multi-recipe workflows safely and efficiently.
notes:
2026-01-06 05:40:51 UTC: EXECUTION STRATEGY - Source: ANALYSIS-TASK-DEPENDENCY-ARCHITECTURE.md Part 6

PARALLELIZATION OPPORTUNITIES:

Wave 0 Execution (Ready Tasks):
- Multiple recipes with no dependencies can execute in parallel
- Agent assignment: distribute across available LLM agents
- Resource limits: max concurrent recipe executions (configurable)
- Example: 4 Wave 0 recipes → 4 agents in parallel

Parallel Group Patterns:
Group A (Research): Read-only recipes, can parallelize freely
Group B (Creation): Write recipes, need coordination to avoid conflicts
Group C (Subtasks): Independent recipe components, full parallelization

AGENT ASSIGNMENT STRATEGY:

Priority-based assignment:
Agent 1: High-priority recipe (gates next wave)
Agent 2: Medium-priority research recipe (parallel)
Agent 3: Low-priority subtask (fills capacity)
Agent 4: Standby (picks up next ready recipe)

Session-aware assignment:
- Each agent gets dedicated session scope
- Session isolation prevents task conflicts
- Multi-session v0.41.0+ supports concurrent agents

Load balancing:
- Distribute wave tasks across agents evenly
- Consider recipe size estimates (small/medium/large)
- Avoid agent starvation (ensure work distribution)

CRITICAL PATH ANALYSIS:

Identify bottleneck recipes:
- Longest sequential chain from start to completion
- Recipes that gate multiple downstream recipes
- Optimization: prioritize critical path recipes

Example Critical Path:
create-epic (Wave 0) → create-tasks (Wave 1) → setup-deps (Wave 2) → finalize (Wave 3)
Length: 4 waves
Bottleneck: create-epic (gates entire workflow)
Optimization: Execute create-epic with highest priority agent

ERROR HANDLING AND ROLLBACK:

Recipe failure modes:
1. Validation failure (Wave 0) - BLOCK: Don't execute, report errors
2. Execution failure (mid-recipe) - ROLLBACK: Undo partial changes
3. Verification failure (post-execution) - RETRY: Fix and re-run
4. Timeout - SUSPEND: Save state, resume later

Rollback strategies:
- Safety backups before destructive recipes
- Transaction log for recipe operations
- Undo script generation for reversible recipes
- Manual intervention for complex failures

RESOURCE MANAGEMENT:

Concurrent execution limits:
- Max parallel agents (configurable per project)
- Max parallel recipes per wave
- Resource reservation (filesystem locks, API rate limits)

Context window management:
- Monitor LLM context usage per agent
- Graceful degradation when approaching limits
- Recipe result caching to reduce context

Performance optimization:
- Recipe result memoization (avoid re-execution)
- Dry-run caching (skip if recipe unchanged)
- Incremental execution (resume from checkpoints)

COORDINATION PROTOCOLS:

Inter-agent communication:
- Shared state via .cleo/*.json files
- Lock files for write coordination
- Event notifications for recipe completion

Wave synchronization:
- All Wave N recipes must complete before Wave N+1 starts
- Barrier pattern: wait for all parallel recipes
- Timeout handling: proceed with partial completion or abort

REFERENCE:
- ANALYSIS Part 6.1: Parallelization Opportunities
- ANALYSIS Part 6.2: Critical Path Analysis
- Multi-session architecture from T1062

tasks.title: Implement O(n) dependency graph algorithm
tasks.description:
Optimize dependency traversal from O(n^2) to O(n) as validated in D2.

Problem: Current Bash implementation spawns 4n jq processes (21s for 840 tasks)
Solution: Single-pass computation with in-memory graph

Implementation:
- src/core/dependency-graph.ts
- Build adjacency list in single JSON parse
- Topological sort for dependency ordering
- Cycle detection for circular reference errors
- Cache invalidation on task changes

Performance target: <30ms for 1000 tasks (was 21s)

tasks.title: EPIC: CLEO Implementation Protocol Unification
tasks.description:
Master epic unifying RCSD research, changeset implementation, and release automation into a coherent CLEO implementation protocol. Coordinates T2204 (research), T2155 (changeset), T2199 (release) under single governance.

## Problem Statement
Three parallel epics have been independently advancing:
- T2204: RCSD Integration Research Consolidation (Sessions A/B/C complete)
- T2155: CLEO Changeset and Release Lifecycle System
- T2199: Release Management & Version Automation

These need unified governance to ensure:
1. Research findings inform implementation decisions
2. Changeset design aligns with release automation needs
3. Protocol handoffs are clearly defined

## Deliverables
- Unified epic tree with clear dependencies
- Protocol specification for RCSD → Implementation handoff
- Protocol specification for Implementation → Release handoff
- Resolved decisions from T2276 (7 pending decisions)
- Coherent implementation roadmap

## Success Criteria
- All three epics reparented under this master epic
- Protocol specifications complete and validated
- No ambiguity in implementation sequence
- Clear ownership and dependencies at every level

tasks.title: BUG: Active sessions never auto-end/archive - causes unbounded accumulation
tasks.description:
## Problem
15+ active sessions accumulating, many from weeks ago. The `session_auto_archive()` function in lib/sessions.sh ONLY targets 'ended' or 'suspended' sessions - it NEVER processes 'active' sessions.

## Root Cause
- `sessionTimeoutHours` config (24h) only generates warnings during `session end` - doesn't auto-transition
- `session gc` runs auto_archive but skips active sessions entirely
- No detection of stale active sessions (lastActivity > X days)

## Evidence
- session_20251230_232225_71660c: lastActivity 2025-12-31 (26 days stale)
- session_20260103_155207_c21933: lastActivity 2026-01-03 (23 days stale)
- 15 active sessions total, should be 1-3 max

## Solution Options
1. Add `retention.autoEndActiveAfterDays` config (default: 7)
2. `session gc --include-active` to end stale active sessions
3. Add `session_auto_end_stale()` function mirroring `session_auto_archive()`
4. Warning during `session start` when stale active sessions exist

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Active sessions older than threshold auto-transitioned to 'ended'
- [ ] `session gc` has option to handle stale active sessions
- [ ] `session doctor` warns about stale active sessions
- [ ] Config `retention.autoEndActiveAfterDays` available
notes: 2026-01-26 17:02:02 UTC: Related to T2318 (Session Lifecycle Management Overhaul). T2322 implements the core fix for this bug.

tasks.title: BUG: session list fails with 'Argument list too long' when sessions.json > ~130KB
tasks.description:
## Problem
session list command fails with 'Argument list too long' when sessions.json grows large.

## Root Cause
scripts/session.sh line 1774 uses:
```bash
--argjson sessions "$sessions"
```

When sessions array is large (332KB in our case with 221 sessions), this exceeds shell argument limit.

## Evidence
```
/home/.../.cleo/scripts/session.sh: line 1771: /usr/bin/jq: Argument list too long
```

## Solution
Use stdin for large JSON instead of --argjson:
```bash
echo "$sessions" | jq -n --slurpfile sessions /dev/stdin ...
```

Or use process substitution:
```bash
jq -n --slurpfile sessions <(echo "$sessions") ...
```

## Affected Commands
- session list
- session doctor  
- Any command reading sessions array

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] session list works with 200+ sessions
- [ ] No argument list too long errors
- [ ] Performance acceptable with large session counts
notes: 2026-01-26 17:02:05 UTC: Related to T2318 (Session Lifecycle Management Overhaul). T2325 implements the fix for this bug.

tasks.title: BUG: session end command cannot accept session ID as argument
tasks.description:
## Problem
In multi-session mode, cannot end a specific session by providing ID as argument.

## Evidence
```bash
cleo session end session_20251231_140205_e07e64 --note 'Test'
# Fails - session ID is ignored

# Only works with env var:
CLEO_SESSION=session_xxx cleo session end --note 'Test'
```

## Root Cause
scripts/session.sh cmd_end() lines 858-862:
```bash
while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
  case $1 in
    --note) note="$2"; shift 2 ;;
    *) shift ;;  # <-- Ignores positional args!
  esac
done
```

## Solution
Add positional session ID parsing like other session subcommands:
```bash
case $1 in
  --note) note="$2"; shift 2 ;;
  session_*) session_id="$1"; shift ;;  # Accept session ID
  *) shift ;;
esac
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- `cleo session end SESSION_ID --note 'text'` works
- `cleo session end --note 'text'` uses current session (backward compat)
- Error message when no session resolvable
notes: 2026-01-26 17:02:08 UTC: Related to T2318 (Session Lifecycle Management Overhaul). T2326 implements the fix for this bug.

tasks.title: EPIC: Contribution Protocol System v2 - JSON-First Multi-Agent Consensus
tasks.description:
Legitimize and harden the Contribution Protocol for structured multi-agent consensus workflows.

## Problem
Current contribution protocol (T2262) uses markdown templates. Markdown is NOT optimized for:
- Machine validation of contributions
- Structured conflict detection
- Multi-agent consensus aggregation
- Programmatic synthesis

## Solution
JSON/JSONL-first contribution system with:
1. Structured contribution format (JSON)
2. Machine-parseable conflict detection
3. Automated consensus aggregation
4. Skill-based workflow integration

## Builds On
- T2262: Contribution Protocol Infrastructure (DONE) - schema, template, lib
- T2204: RCSD Integration Research Consolidation - first consumer

## Deliverables
1. JSON contribution format spec
2. JSONL manifest for contribution tracking
3. Contribution Protocol Skill (/contribution)
4. Usage guide (docs/guides/CONTRIBUTION-PROTOCOL-GUIDE.md)
5. Conflict detection automation
6. Consensus aggregation tooling
7. RCSD pipeline integration updates

## Success Criteria
- Contributions are 100% JSON (no markdown decisions)
- Conflicts machine-detectable
- Consensus can be computed programmatically
- Skill provides guided workflow for agents

tasks.title: Implement consensus aggregation tooling
tasks.description:
Implement programmatic consensus computation from contributions.

## Depends On
- T2314: Conflict detection (need conflicts identified first)

## Deliverable
Add to `lib/contribution-protocol.sh`:

### Functions

```bash
contribution_compute_consensus()
  # Input: epic_id
  # Output: JSON consensus object with confidence-weighted decisions
  
contribution_weighted_vote()
  # Input: decisions[] (from multiple sessions)
  # Output: {winner: string, confidence: float, votes: [...]}
  
contribution_generate_synthesis()
  # Input: epic_id
  # Output: Unified consensus document ready for T2208-style synthesis
```

### Consensus Algorithm
1. Group decisions by questionId
2. Weight by confidence score
3. Apply voting rules:
   - Unanimous = HIGH confidence
   - Majority = MEDIUM confidence
   - Split = HITL required
4. Flag unresolved for human review

### Output Format
```json
{
  "consensus": {
    "epicId": "T2204",
    "contributionCount": 3,
    "decisions": [
      {
        "questionId": "Q1",
        "answer": "...",
        "confidence": 0.92,
        "votingResult": "unanimous",
        "supportingSessions": ["a", "b", "c"]
      }
    ],
    "unresolved": [...],
    "hitlRequired": true/false
  }
}
```

tasks.title: Epic: Cross-Agent Communication Protocol Unification
tasks.description:
Unify the orchestrator protocol, subagent protocol, manifest system, and context tracking into a cohesive cross-agent communication system. Current state has fragmented components that work independently but lack proper integration, enforcement, and generalization.

## Problem Statement

1. Protocol Injection Not Enforced: Orchestrator SHOULD inject subagent protocol but this is not enforced
2. Research Naming Too Narrow: Manifest system can handle ANY subagent output, not just research
3. Context Tracking Not Integrated: Context monitoring not used in orchestrator decisions
4. No Unified Consensus Mechanism: Contribution protocol not integrated with orchestrator
5. Protocol Violation Detection Missing: Orchestrator reading outputs directly instead of manifests

## Success Criteria

1. Orchestrator MUST inject protocol block to every spawned subagent
2. Manifest system generalized from research-outputs to agent-outputs
3. Context tracking integrated into orchestrator spawn decisions
4. Protocol compliance verified before spawning next agent
5. Unified agent handoff abstraction across all components

tasks.title: Design: Unified Agent Handoff Abstraction
tasks.description:
Design the unified abstraction layer for agent handoffs that replaces the current research-centric model.

## Requirements

1. Generalize from research-outputs to agent-outputs
2. Support multiple output types: research, implementation, validation, review
3. Define standard manifest entry schema for all agent types
4. Establish handoff protocol that works for any subagent type

## Considerations

- Backward compatibility with existing research-outputs
- Migration path for existing MANIFEST.jsonl files
- Token system for protocol injection
- Integration with CLEO task lifecycle

## Deliverables

- RFC-style design document
- Updated manifest schema definition
- Migration strategy document

tasks.title: Implement: Contribution Protocol Integration
tasks.description:
Integrate the contribution protocol with the unified agent handoff system.

## Requirements

1. Contribution protocol works with generalized agent-outputs
2. Consensus computation uses manifest entries
3. HITL gates integrated with orchestrator workflow
4. Synthesis generation produces agent-output format

## Integration Points

1. lib/contribution-protocol.sh - Update to use agent-outputs
2. lib/agent-manifest.sh - Support contribution entries
3. ct-orchestrator/SKILL.md - Document consensus workflow

## Workflow

1. Orchestrator spawns multiple research agents
2. Each agent writes to agent-outputs/MANIFEST.jsonl
3. Contribution protocol detects conflicts from manifest
4. Consensus computed using weighted voting
5. HITL gate if split votes
6. Synthesis written to agent-outputs

## Deliverables

- Updated contribution-protocol.sh
- Integration tests for consensus workflow
- Documentation updates

tasks.title: Bug: cleo release ship command times out during execution
tasks.description:
## Problem
The cleo release ship command hangs/times out during execution, preventing automated release workflows.

## Observed Behavior
- Command: cleo release ship v0.76.0 --write-changelog
- Result: Hangs indefinitely, no output produced
- Workaround: Manual changelog updates and direct todo.json modifications required

## Suspected Areas
1. cmd_ship() function in scripts/release.sh (line 546+)
2. populate_release_tasks() - auto-discovery may be slow with large task sets
3. generate_changelog() - changelog generation from lib/changelog.sh
4. append_to_changelog() - file write operations
5. validate_release() - validation gates

## Impact
- Blocks automated CI/CD release workflows
- Forces manual intervention for every release
- Breaks RCSD-IVTR release protocol automation

## RCSD-IVTR Workflow
This epic follows RCSD-IVTR protocol:
- Research: Profile and identify bottleneck
- Specification: Define performance requirements
- Decomposition: Break fix into atomic tasks
- Implementation: Fix the bottleneck
- Validation: Verify acceptable performance

tasks.title: Research: Folder Structure & Memory-Trees Agent Architecture
tasks.description:
Multi-phase research initiative investigating two interconnected topics:

1. **Codebase Folder Structure Analysis**: Evaluate current flat folder organization, identify benefits/drawbacks, and explore reorganization possibilities.

2. **Memory-Trees Subagent Architecture**: Novel concept for enhancing agent context traversal:
   - Memory trees as folder-anchored context zones
   - 4-5 tier pyramid with subagents passing information
   - Cross-cutting capability between memory trees (like an internal API)
   - More precise context, less contextual rot
   - Subagents guiding information from one subfolder to another

**Scope**: Investigation and research ONLY - no changes to codebase.

**Deliverables**:
- Current folder structure analysis report
- Memory-trees architecture concept document
- Consensus on potential benefits/risks
- Recommendations for CLEO enhancement (if warranted)

tasks.title: Bug: CLI session commands have poor output/feedback
tasks.description:
Multiple CLI UX issues found during orchestrator workflow:

ISSUES IDENTIFIED:

1. **cleo focus set** returns no output/confirmation
   - Hard to verify if focus was set without additional command
   - Should return: {success: true, focusedTask: 'Txxx'}

2. **cleo session start** fails silently when piped through jq
   - Output swallowed, no error visible
   - Should always produce parseable JSON output

3. **Session persistence** unreliable across conversation turns
   - .current-session file sometimes deleted/changed unexpectedly
   - Makes multi-turn orchestration difficult

4. **cleo session switch** returns no output
   - No confirmation that switch succeeded
   - Should return: {success: true, sessionId: 'xxx'}

5. **General**: Many commands return empty when piped to jq
   - Inconsistent JSON output handling
   - Some commands output to stderr, some to stdout

IMPACT:
- Orchestrator workflows require extra verification commands
- Context budget wasted on confirmation checks
- Silent failures hard to debug

SUGGESTED FIX:
- All mutating commands MUST return JSON with {success, ...data}
- All commands MUST output to stdout (errors to stderr)
- Session state MUST be atomic and persistent

PROVENANCE: Discovered during T2802/T2810 orchestrator work

tasks.title: Research: Autonomous Self-Improvement Ticket Logging System
tasks.description:
Research and design automated system for agents to log self-improvement tickets when witnessing issues during operation.

PROBLEM:
- Agents discover bugs/issues during work but may not log them
- No enforced mechanism to capture witnessed issues
- Cross-provider CLI agents (Claude Code, Codex, Gemini CLI, Kimi, etc.) need unified approach

RESEARCH AREAS:
1. **Detection Patterns**: What types of issues should trigger auto-logging?
   - CLI output failures (silent errors, swallowed output)
   - Session state inconsistencies
   - Protocol violations
   - Unexpected behavior patterns

2. **Logging Mechanism**: How to enforce ticket creation?
   - Hook-based (PostToolUse hooks detect anomalies)
   - Manifest-based (agents MUST log issues to manifest)
   - Compliance check (validate issues were logged)

3. **Cross-Provider Compatibility**: Design for multi-agent ecosystem
   - Claude Code hooks
   - Codex/OpenAI function calling patterns
   - Gemini CLI integration
   - Kimi and other emerging agents
   - Common protocol/schema for issue logging

4. **Autonomy vs Control**: Balance between auto-logging and noise
   - Severity thresholds for auto-create
   - Dedup mechanism (don't create duplicate tickets)
   - Human review queue vs direct creation

DESIRED OUTPUT:
- Design doc for autonomous issue logging
- Proposed schema for cross-provider compatibility
- Hook/trigger implementation strategy
- Integration points with CLEO task system

PROVENANCE: Discovered need during T2802 orchestrator work - multiple CLI issues went unlogged until manually noticed
notes:
2026-01-30 19:33:58 UTC: ADDITIONAL SCOPE - Bug-Log for Non-Dogfooding Users:

When users run CLEO on projects OTHER than CLEO itself (not dogfooding), they may still discover CLEO bugs/improvements. Need mechanism to:

1. Local Bug-Log file (.cleo/bug-log.json) to capture issues
2. Optional upstream reporting (with user consent)
3. Federated improvement collection across all CLEO installations
4. Separate from project tasks - these are CLEO improvements, not project work

Consider: cleo bug-report command that:
- Creates local log entry
- Optionally submits to central CLEO issue tracker
- Includes context (version, command, error, reproduction steps)
- Privacy-conscious (no project data leaked)

This enables the CLEO ecosystem to benefit from ALL users' discoveries, not just maintainers dogfooding.

tasks.title: Bug: Pre-commit hook checks working dir not staged files
tasks.description:
Drift detection pre-commit hook checks working directory instead of staged files.

## Current Behavior
```bash
# Fix is staged but hook still fails
git diff --cached | grep backfill  # Shows fix IS staged
git commit  # FAILS - hook checks working dir
```

## Expected Behavior
Hook should check staged content using:
```bash
git show :docs/commands/COMMANDS-INDEX.json
```

## Fix Location
.git/hooks/pre-commit or dev/skills/ct-docs-sync/scripts/detect-drift.sh

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Hook uses git show for staged files
- [ ] Valid commits with staged fixes pass
notes: 2026-02-01 02:37:35 UTC: Deferred - pre-commit hook issue documented, workaround is --no-verify

tasks.title: Bug: Session start fails when epic has no pending tasks
tasks.description:
Can't start session with --auto-focus when all epic tasks are done.

## Current Behavior
```
cleo session start --scope epic:T2666 --auto-focus
Error: E_SCOPE_EMPTY - No pending tasks in scope for auto-focus
```

## Expected Behavior
Should allow session start even with no pending tasks, or provide better workflow.

## Options
1. Allow session without focus when all done
2. Auto-create 'followup' task for notes/commits
3. Allow --no-focus flag

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Can start session on completed epic for notes/commit
- [ ] Clear workflow for post-completion work
notes: 2026-02-01 02:37:39 UTC: Deferred - session start issue documented, workaround is to use existing pending task

This is the least invasive solution that preserves existing behavior while enabling post-completion workflows.

tasks.description: Create comprehensive TypeScript types in src/types/: GatewayRequest, GatewayResponse, DomainOperation, ErrorResponse, all domain-specific param/result types. Export from src/types/index.ts. Must cover all 98 operations with full type safety.

tasks.title: Implement domain router with operation dispatch
tasks.description: Create src/lib/router.ts implementing domain routing logic. Parse domain+operation from request, validate against allowed operations matrix, dispatch to appropriate handler. Include operation validation and unknown operation handling with proper error codes.

tasks.title: Implement response formatter with _meta envelope
tasks.description: Create src/lib/response.ts for consistent response formatting. Implement success(), error(), partial() helpers. Include _meta block (gateway, domain, operation, version, timestamp, duration_ms). Map exit codes to error responses with fix suggestions.

tasks.title: Implement exit code mapping and error handling
tasks.description: Create src/lib/errors.ts with complete exit code enum (0-100+), error code constants (E_*), and mapping functions. Include isRetryable(), getErrorFix(), getAlternatives() for actionable error responses per MCP-SERVER-SPECIFICATION.md Section 5.

tasks.title: Implement CLI executor wrapper
tasks.description: Create src/lib/cli-executor.ts to wrap cleo CLI commands. Execute via child_process with proper escaping, capture stdout/stderr, parse JSON output, map exit codes. Handle timeout, retries for code 7, and proper cleanup.

tasks.title: Implement cleo_query gateway tool
tasks.description: Create src/gateways/query.ts implementing the cleo_query MCP tool. Register with MCP server, define inputSchema per spec Section 2.1.1, route to domain handlers, enforce read-only semantics. Support caching if config.mcp.features.queryCache enabled.

tasks.title: Implement tasks domain handler (19 operations)
tasks.description: Create src/domains/tasks.ts with all 19 task operations. Query ops: get, list, find, exists, tree, blockers, deps, analyze, next. Mutate ops: create, update, complete, delete, archive, unarchive, reparent, promote, reorder, reopen. Map to cleo CLI commands.

tasks.title: Implement orchestrate domain handler (12 operations)
tasks.description: Create src/domains/orchestrate.ts with all 12 orchestration operations. Query ops: status, next, ready, analyze, context, waves, skill.list. Mutate ops: startup, spawn, validate, parallel.start, parallel.end. Critical for 2-tier subagent architecture.

tasks.title: Implement protocol enforcement middleware
tasks.description: Create src/lib/protocol-enforcement.ts to validate protocol compliance on mutate operations. Check RCSD-IVTR requirements per spec Section 4.2. Return exit codes 60-70 for violations. Integrate with validate domain for runtime checks.

tasks.title: Implement manifest integration for MCP operations
tasks.description: Create src/lib/manifest.ts for MANIFEST.jsonl operations. Implement append with flock, read with filtering, validation per spec Section 6. Ensure single-line JSON, required fields, and agent_type mapping.

tasks.title: Implement audit logging for mutations
tasks.description: Create src/lib/audit.ts for mutation audit trail. Log all cleo_mutate operations to .cleo/mcp-audit.jsonl with timestamp, operation, params, result, duration. Support log rotation and configurable retention.

tasks.title: Create unit tests for domain handlers
tasks.description: Create tests/mcp/unit/ with test files for each domain handler. Test all 98 operations with mocked CLI responses. Cover success paths, error handling, parameter validation, and response formatting. Target 90%+ coverage.

tasks.title: Create integration tests for MCP gateways
tasks.description: Create tests/mcp/integration/ testing full request→response flow through gateways. Test cleo_query and cleo_mutate with real CLI execution against test fixtures. Verify exit code mapping, response envelopes, and error handling.

tasks.title: Create protocol compliance tests
tasks.description: Create tests/mcp/protocol/ testing RCSD-IVTR enforcement. Verify exit codes 60-70 for protocol violations, lifecycle gate blocking (exit 75), and verification gate dependencies. Test all 9 protocols defined in spec Section 4.2.

tasks.title: Create MCP server API documentation
tasks.description: Create docs/mcp/API.md with complete API reference. Document all 98 operations with parameters, return types, examples, and error codes. Generate from TypeScript types. Include curl examples for testing.

tasks.title: Create JSON schemas for MCP operations
tasks.description: Create schemas/mcp/ with JSON Schema definitions for all request/response types. Generate from TypeScript types. Include schemas for each domain's params and results. Enable runtime validation.

tasks.description: Create src/index.ts as MCP server entry point. Initialize server with stdio transport, register cleo_query and cleo_mutate tools, load config, set up error handling. Export for npm package consumption.

tasks.description: Finalize package.json with proper metadata, bin entry for CLI, main/types entries for library use. Add build scripts (tsc), test scripts (jest), prepublish hooks. Create README.md for npm.

tasks.description: Create src/lib/config.ts to load MCP settings from .cleo/config.json. Handle: mcp.enabled, mcp.transport, mcp.features (queryCache, auditLog, strictValidation), lifecycleEnforcement, protocolValidation.

tasks.title: Implement cleo_mutate gateway tool
tasks.description: Create src/gateways/mutate.ts implementing the cleo_mutate MCP tool. Register with MCP server, define inputSchema per spec Section 2.2.1, route to domain handlers, enforce audit logging.

tasks.title: Implement session domain handler (12 operations)
tasks.description: Create src/domains/session.ts with all 12 session operations. Query: status, list, show, focus.get, history. Mutate: start, end, resume, suspend, focus.set, focus.clear, gc.

tasks.title: Implement lifecycle domain handler (10 operations)
tasks.description: Create src/domains/lifecycle.ts with all 10 lifecycle operations. Query: check, status, history, gates, prerequisites. Mutate: progress, skip, reset, gate.pass, gate.fail.

tasks.title: Research: Profile test suite performance and identify bottlenecks
tasks.description:
Profile the test suite to identify:
1. Slowest test files (time per file)
2. Tests that timeout at 60s limit
3. Tests that cannot be parallelized (shared state)
4. Memory/CPU usage patterns

Output: Performance baseline document with specific bottlenecks identified.

tasks.title: Fix init script not creating CLAUDE.md, AGENTS.md, GEMINI.md in new projects
tasks.description:
Bug fix: init.sh failed to create agent documentation files due to two issues:
1. IFS modification by backup.sh broke word splitting in for loop
2. Arithmetic increment operations failed with set -e when counter was 0

Fixed by:
- Resetting IFS before agent loop and restoring after
- Adding || true to all increment operations
- Changed to ar_list_agents to always include claude-code
notes: [COMPLETED 2026-02-01T08:09:05Z] Fixed init.sh: reset IFS before agent loop, added || true to increment ops, changed to ar_list_agents. All agent docs now created correctly.

tasks.title: EPIC: Provable Token Savings Benchmark
tasks.description:
Create reproducible benchmark to PROVE CLEO saves tokens. Must produce real numbers from Claude Code API, not estimates. Goal: Publish claims that other developers can verify.

## Success Criteria
- Real token data from Claude Code (via OTel or API logs)
- A/B comparison: manifest reads vs full file reads
- Reproducible benchmark script anyone can run
- Published results with methodology

## Anti-Goals
- No more estimated tokens (4 chars = 1 token)
- No fake 100% compliance scores
- No claims without data

tasks.title: Research: How Claude Code exposes token usage
tasks.description: Investigate all methods Claude Code exposes token data: OTel metrics, API responses, transcript files, environment variables. Document exact fields and formats.

tasks.title: Implement real token capture from Claude Code
tasks.description: Update lib/token-estimation.sh to capture REAL tokens from Claude Code sources instead of estimates. Parse OTel files, transcript JSON, or API response logs.

tasks.title: Create A/B benchmark: manifest vs full-file reads
tasks.description: Create dev/benchmark-token-savings.sh that runs identical tasks using: A) manifest-based lookups, B) full file reads. Measure actual token consumption for each.

tasks.title: Run benchmark and collect baseline data
tasks.description: Execute A/B benchmark across 10+ real tasks. Record: task ID, method (A/B), input tokens, output tokens, total cost. Store in .cleo/metrics/BENCHMARK.jsonl

tasks.title: Publish benchmark results with methodology
tasks.description: Create docs/BENCHMARK-RESULTS.md with: methodology, raw data, statistical analysis, reproducibility instructions. Claims must be verifiable by third parties.
